title: A simple CKMR model for Delfinus mendax
text:
Diagnostics
Diagnostics for CKMR can be tricky as there is often a very small amount of observed POPs.
This example actually contains a huge amount of POPs compared to what we would usually observe, so we can compare observed vs. expected POPs for each sampling year and juvenile birth year.
TO-DO.
For a normal dataset with less POPs we could do the same over aggregated time-periods (e.g. first half vs. second half time-series).

title: Fish-like species: a simple CKMR model for Notogorgius poutii
text:
Code
supp <- function(x) suppressWarnings(suppressMessages(x))
supp(library(tidyverse)) # for the tutorial
library(data.table) %>% supp

## CKMR libraries
library(mvbutils) %>% supp # various low-level utilities, eg cq()
library(offarray) %>% supp # arrays/vectors don't have to start at 1 any more! Freedom!
library(debug) %>% supp # so we can watch the fun
library(atease) %>% supp

## for plotting:
library(ggplot2) %>% supp
library(cowplot); theme_set(theme_cowplot(font_size=10))
library(colorspace)
library(patchwork) %>% supp

source('../plonk/ckmr_funs.r') # tutorial functions
source('../plonk/turn_off_bc.r') # turn-off the byte-compiler (required for offarray to work)

load( '../plonk/samp_notog1.rda') # object samp_notog1
agemat <- samp_notog1@public$Amat # age at maturity for this species
In this CKMR exercise we combine two types of close-kin marks (parent-offsprings and half-siblings) in order to scale population size for a species where fecundity changes with age (i.e. fish-like).
As this is a commercially-exploited species, the population model will also account for annual catch data.

title: Fish-like species: a simple CKMR model for Notogorgius poutii
text:
Half-sibling pairs
So far we have considered direct marks only, whereby a juvenile “marks” its parent upon being born and for the parent mark to be recaptured we have to sample both the juvenile and its marked parent (i.e., POPs). Let’s now move on to the `indirect’ marks, the half-sibling pairs (HSPs). Here, the parent mark is recaptured when we have sampled two (or more) of its offspring over different cohorts. In the process, we found out a few things about the parent from the characteristics of its offspring (even though we’ve never actually seen the parent!). First, the parent was mature when the oldest of the sibling was born and second, the parent was still alive when the youngest of the sibling was born. For fish-like species, we also know that the parent contributed more to the total reproductive output the year that the youngest of the sibling was born (since it grew in size and thus, increased its fecundity).
Let’s look at the number of possible combinations between potential half-sibling pairs. First, note that we’re not accounting for adults in HSPs comparison to avoid including grand-parents. So we’re only considering samples that are possibly juveniles (i.e. 7 years old or younger).
For half-siblings, we are only interested in the year they were born (i.e. the cohort they belong to). The dataset has a similar format to that for POPs, that is two columns that index the record in samp_notog1$Samps. Of note the pairs are ordered (by convention) to list the youngest of the sibling first, the oldest second. Comparisons should only be made in one direction (to avoid double-counting) so we pick oldest to youngest and retain it (including in likelihood calculations).

head(samp_notog1$HSPs)

     [,1] [,2]
[1,] 1138 1688
[2,] 1158 2630
[3,] 1175 2076
[4,] 1782 2923
[5,] 1268 1897
[6,] 1419 2364


We can look at the detected HSPs by combination of birth years and compare that to the number of possible pairwise combinations between different birth years (see env$n_comp_HSP).


Code
bbdf <- with(samp_notog1, data.frame(B1=Samps$B[HSPs[,1]],
                                     B2=Samps$B[HSPs[,2]]))
bbdfag <- bbdf %>% group_by(B1, B2) %>% tally # count by combinations of birth year

hxl <- range(filter(samp_notog1$Samps, poss_off)$B) + c(-0.5, 0.5)

hc1 <- ggplot(bbdfag, aes(B1, B2, fill=n)) + geom_tile(show.legend=FALSE) +
    geom_text(aes(label=n), size=2.5) +
    scale_fill_gradientn(colours=rev(sequential_hcl(40, 'Emrld'))) +
    geom_hline(yintercept=seq(hxl[1], hxl[2]), colour='grey', size=0.25) +
    geom_vline(xintercept=seq(hxl[1], hxl[2]), colour='grey', size=0.25) +    
    annotate('text', x=-Inf, y=Inf, label=paste('n =', nrow(bbdf)), vjust=1.2, hjust=-0.5) +
    xlab('') +
    ylab('Birth year of older sibling\n') + xlim(hxl) + ylim(hxl) +

    ggtitle('Detected HSPs')

hspdf <- samp_notog1$Samps %>% filter(poss_off) %>%
    group_by(B) %>% tally
## create df with all possible pairwise combinations of birthyears,
## filter to only keep combinations where B2 > B1 (note '>'---no same cohort comparisons)
hspcomp <- expand(hspdf %>% group_by(B, n),
                  rename(hspdf, B2=B, n2=n) %>% group_by(B2, n2)) %>% filter(B2 > B)

hspcomp$Num <- with(hspcomp, n * n2) # number of pairwise comparisons

hc2 <- ggplot(hspcomp, aes(B, B2, fill=Num)) + 
 geom_tile(show.legend=FALSE, colour='grey') +
    geom_text(aes(label=n), size=2.5) +
    scale_fill_gradientn(colours=rev(sequential_hcl(40, 'Emrld'))) +
    xlab('\nBirth year of younger sibling') +
    ylab('') + xlim(hxl) + ylim(hxl) +
    geom_hline(yintercept=seq(hxl[1], hxl[2]), colour='grey', size=0.25) +
    geom_vline(xintercept=seq(hxl[1], hxl[2]), colour='grey', size=0.25) +
    ggtitle('# of valid comparisons')

hc1 + hc2 + theme(axis.title.x=element_text(hjust=-0.85)) + plot_layout(nrow=1)





It’s also useful to look at the age difference between the detected half-siblings, as that tells us something about adult survival (and will indeed inform the population model with regards to \(M\)):


Code
bbdf$diff <- with(bbdf, B2 - B1)

ggplot(bbdf, aes(diff)) + geom_histogram() +
    xlab('\nAge difference') +
    ylab('Count\n')


`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.





Code
## compare that to the possible age difference given all the pairwise comparisons
# hspcomp$diff <- with(hspcomp, B2 - B1)
# table(with(hspcomp, rep(diff, Num)))


So, most HSPs we detected are separated by one to three years, with a few that go up to 6 years. We’re also learning about parent age, e.g. the parent for the HSPs separated by 6 years was at least 11 years old when they produced the youngest offspring (given age-at-maturity).

title: Fish-like species: a simple CKMR model for Notogorgius poutii
text:
The likelihood for parent-offspring pairs
For POPs, we first need to generate an estimate of fecundity-at-age given wtfecpar:
$ F_a = W_a ^ $
(\(F_a\) is fecata, \(W_a\) is weight and \(\alpha\) is wtfecpar).
Then, we can get the Total Reproductive Output (TRO) for each year as the sum-product of the abundance-by-age for that year and the fecundity by age:

  TRO <- offarray(
      N_ya[,ADAGES] %**% fecata[ ADAGES], # multiplies than sums across rows
      first=min_Bju,
      last=max_Bju)

(We index this by juvenile birth year as we need TRO by birth year in the likelihood).
We then loop through each combination of juvenile birth year, adult sampling year and adult age to compute the probability that an adult of age \(A\) sampled in year \(Y\) is the parent of a juvenile born in year \(B\). That probability is the ratio of the fecundity of the adult in year in year \(B\) (i.e. the fecundity of an adult of age \(A\) - (\(Y - B\))) to the total reproductive output in year \(B\), TRO[Bju]. The probability is also scaled by whether the adult would have been mature and still alive in year \(B\):

Pr_POP <- autoloop( Bju=Bju_range, Yad=Yad_range, Aad=ADAGES, {
      Bad <- Yad - Aad
      ( Bju <= Yad ) *          # was ad still alive at B[ju] ?
      ( Bju >= Amat + Bad ) *   # was ad mature at B[ju] ?
      ( fec_fn( Aad - (Yad-Bju)) / TRO[ Bju]) # ERRO if above
    })

… and that’s it for the POP component of the likelihood. We can then compute the expected number of POPs as the product of this probability and the number of possible comparisons for each birth year, sampling year and adult age strata (see below).

title: Fish-like species: a simple CKMR model for Notogorgius poutii
text:
The likelihood for half-sibling pairs
Computing the probability of observing a half-sibling pair is a bit more complicated, so it’s been broken down into a few steps.
Step 1: Cumulative survival—what is the probability that an adult of age A who was the parent of a sibling born in year B1 survived to year B2 to become the parent of the second sibling.
That number is simply the ratio of the abundance of adults of age A in year B1 to the abundance of adults of age A + (B2 - B1) in year B2, since the adults will be B2 - B1 years older:


Code
psurv_ayy <- autoloop( a1=ADAGES, y1=Bju_range, y2=Bju_range, {
    
      dy <- y2-y1 # Age difference between cohorts
      a2 <- a1 + abs(dy) # Adult's age when second cohort was born:
      a2_clip <- pmin(a2, AMAX) # making sure we don't allow Adults > AMAX
      # (in case adults would have add to be older than AMAX)

      ans <- (dy >= 0) *      # forwards only (i.e. y2 > y1 to avoid double-counting)
          (a2 <= AMAX) *      # plus-group dies entirely
          (N_ya[ y2, a2_clip] / N_ya[ y1, a1]) # the probability of survival
    return(ans)
    })


Since we don’t know the age of the parent (we haven’t sampled it—it’s an indirect mark), we need to compute the probability across all possible parent ages (i.e. 5 to 12) for a given sibling pair.
Step 2: Get the contribution to TRO of the parent of unknown age in year B1 and in year B2.
For convenience, we start by computing the expected contribution to TRO of each adult cohort of age a for each juvenile birth year y:

Pr_Mum1Age <- autoloop( y=Bju_range, a=ADAGES, {
    return( N_ya[ y, a] * fecata[ a] / TRO[ y])
    })

Step 3:
We combine all the previously computed quantities to estimate the joint probability that an adult of a given age A was the parent of an offspring born in year B1 and an offspring born in year B2. For this we account for the parent’s contribution to TRO in B1, the probability of surviving to B2, and the parent’s contribution to TRO in B2, i.e. the product of: - the proportion of adults of age A surviving from B1 to B2 - the contribution of the parent of age A + B2 - B1 to TRO in year B2 - the abundance of parents of age A in B1 scaled by their contribution to TRO in that year (computed in Step 2):

  Pr_HSP_and_Mum1Age <- autoloop( B1=Bju_range, B2=Bju_range, PARAGE=ADAGES, {
      
      # Given on adult (mum)'s age at B1 (ie PARAGE)
      # Probability that adult of age A survived from B1 to B2 *
      # Contribution to TRO in B2 of adults of age PARAGE in B2
      Pr_HSP_cond <- (B1 < B2) * psurv_ayy[ PARAGE, B1, B2] * fec_fn( PARAGE+B2-B1) / TRO[ B2]

    return( Pr_HSP_cond * Pr_Mum1Age[ B1, PARAGE]) # * contribution to TRO in B1 of adult *cohort* of age PARAGE

  })

To get the probability that two HSPs are related across all possible parent ages at B1 we just Pr_HSP_and_Mum1Age over all parent ages:

  Pr_HSP <- sumover( Pr_HSP_and_Mum1Age, 'PARAGE')

Pr_HSP is the probability of a half-sibling pairs for all combinations of B1 and B2 over all possible parent ages at B1.
Now, we just need to adjust these to account for the proportion of false negative detection for half-siblings, Pr_FNeg_HSP (in this example it’s set to 0 but typically could be 15%).

  Pr_HSP <- Pr_HSP * (1-Pr_FNeg_HSP) # allow for known loss-rate due to kinference

And now, we can compile the joint likelihoods for the expected probability of POPs and HSPs given our observations:

 lglk <- sum( dpois( n_POP, lambda=n_comp_POP*Pr_POP, log=TRUE)) +
     sum( dpois( n_HSP, lambda=n_comp_HSP*Pr_HSP, log=TRUE))
